body:
Seems like it should work, especially since the redirection happens before any tests run. I suspect we are capturing it and throwing it away, since it does not apply to any individual test output.

When you  talk about the output triggering events, I hope you are not expecting it to be synchronous. Output from each test does not go to the console until the test is finished. Unless we do something new and different, Output for a suite will not arrive until the suite is finished.

Have you tried using error output?

Depending on how this is used, we may want to make capture of text output an option. If we don't capture it, folks wanting to write to the test output would have to use the TestContext to write messages.

We do not need it to be synchronous, printing at the end of the tests should be fine. The events are things such as "Upload file: path-to-file.file".

`Console.Error.WriteLine ("FixSetUp");` exhibits the same behavior (does not print to console).

> folks wanting to write to the test output would have to use the TestContext to write messages.

Are you implying `TestContext.WriteLine ("FixSetup")` should work in the "OneTimeSetUp" and "OneTimeTearDown" annotated methods? I tested this and it is does not print (same behavior as Console) - FYI.
That's good info. I believe you will actually find the output in the xml result file even though the console is not picking it up. That tells us a bit about where the problem is.
I can confirm that neither the `Console` nor the `TestContext` is output to the console for `OneTimeSetUp` or `OneTimeTearDown`, but as you expected @CharliePoole, they are in the test result file.

issue.title: Treat OneTimeSetup and OneTimeTearDown as separate work items

milestone.description:
This release of NUnit expands on parallel test execution to allow test methods to
be run in parallel. Please see the [Parallelizable Attribute](https://github.com/nunit/docs/wiki/Parallelizable-Attribute)
for more information.

NUnit 3.7 also drops the Portable build of the framework and replaces it with a
.NET Standard 1.3 version to compliment the .NET Standard 1.6 version. This change
enables several constraints and other features in the .NET Standard builds that
weren't available in portable like Path and Directory based asserts.

The AssertionHelper class has been deprecated because it is seldom used and has
not received any of the updates that Asserts and Constraints receive. If your code
is using the AssertionHelper class, we recommend that you migrate your asserts.

issue.body:
Issue #1062 and pr #1086 highlight a minor problem with the fact that the setup and tear down are treated very similarly, the output from the setup ends up showing up after the tests which is potentially confusing.

If this is fixed, the fix in pr #1086 should be updated to output the setup before the tests.

body:
This was marked as closed:done in November 2015. I just ran into this issue in November 2016 with version 3.5 of Nunit. Console.WriteLine from inside [OneTimeSetup] and [OneTimeTearDown] does not produce output, but Console.WriteLine from inside [Test] does produce output.

Is this expected to have been fixed?

This issue was the start of the discussion that eventually led to the provision of immediate output.

To summarize, NUnit supports two kinds of output: standard and immediate.

Standard output is produced using Console.Write and TextContext.Write. The text is attached to the test result.

Immediate output is produced by Console.Error, TextContext.Error and TextContext.Progress. It is displayed immediately when received.

Standard output comes to the console runner at the end of the test. It is displayed for test cases but not currently for suites. The OneTimeSetUp is associated with the suite (fixture). Normally, the console only displays info from the fixture if the OneTimeSetUp fails.

You could create an issue to change this behavior or you could use immediate output.
Thanks! I'll try TestContext.Progress.WriteLine() as a work-around. That will write to STDOUT instead of STDERR, correct?

The console runner uses stdout to write everything that comes from a test, so it goes to the console screen unless you used a command-line option to redirect it. In the case of error output, it displays in red.

Our advice on test class constructors has remained the same for many years.
They should be very sparse if they exist at all. Remember that NUnit makes
no guarantees as to when or even how many times your class is constructed.
That's why the various setup methods exist.

In your case, there is the added problem of trying to use TextContext at a
time when no test is being executed. That output is simply discarded.

On Nov 14, 2016 2:35 AM, "Grimace of Despair" notifications@github.com
wrote:

> I'm experiencing a similar issue. I've got a static constructor, which can
> throw an exception, resulting in:
> 
> Test Name:  GivenAServiceContract_WhenListingTheOperationContracts_ThenTheirNamesShouldBeUnique
> Test FullName:  ServiceContractTests.GivenAServiceContract_WhenListingTheOperationContracts_ThenTheirNamesShouldBeUnique
> Test Source:    C:\Src\ServiceContractTests.cs : line 27
> Test Outcome:   Failed
> Test Duration:  0:00:00.0000001
> 
> Result Message:
> OneTimeSetUp: System.TypeInitializationException : The type initializer for 'ServiceContractTests' threw an exception.
>   ----> System.Exception : Foo bar
> 
> I'm trying to use TestCases based on the outcome of that static
> constructor:
> 
> [TestFixture]public class ServiceContractTests
> {
>     private static HashSet<Type> ServiceContracts;
> 
> ```
> static ServiceContractTests()
> {
>     TestContext.Progress.WriteLine("Custom message");
>     TestContext.Error.WriteLine("Custom message");
>     Console.WriteLine("Custom message");
>     Console.Error.WriteLine("Custom message");
>     throw new Exception("Foo bar");
> }
> 
> [Test]
> [TestCaseSource("ServiceContracts")]
> public void GivenAServiceContract_WhenListingTheOperationContracts_ThenTheirNamesShouldBeUnique(Type interfaceType) {
> }
> ```
> 
> }
> 
> None of the Custom messages end up in my Visual Studio test console.
> 
> 
> You are receiving this because you were assigned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/nunit/nunit/issues/1062#issuecomment-260301880, or mute
> the thread
> https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ACjfhRcH7yTpaoo4tIoEBNjcXL6xT7aSks5q-DmNgaJpZM4Gn1Lk
> .

Ok, clear. Sorry for having disregarded these apparently long lasting guidelines, so thanks for your patience on that :)

By the nature of the error message, I was under the impression that under the hood, OneTimeSetup would result in the same behaviour as a static constructor. Deducting from that, I was expecting some data in the output, if it wasn't for the fact that the exception details _do_ end up in there.

Otoh, quite frankly, I try avoid static constructors in tests too, but as far as I could tell, that's the only way of using TestCaseSource. So would you advice on ditching TestCaseSource altogether and refactoring my test? Or am I actually missing on how to properly apply TestCaseSource for my scenario?

@GrimaceOfDespair you are using `TestCaseSource` incorrectly. I assume that your static constructor is being used to initialize your `TestCaseSource`. That works, but most people make the `TestCaseSource` a property or method that contains the code that you have in your static constructor and then `yield return` the results.

Another small tip, if you have the `TestCaseSource` on a test, you don't need the `[Test]` attribute.
